Coverage increased (+0.003%) to 70.627% when pulling **9056783c962cd1093eee3eca718bdbc5b42e554a on sb2nov:BEAM-2636-bq-override** into **a6f460fe3b760aafbc748ae18956f0f2c1fedfad on apache:master**.
Thanks will do the cherry pick if there is a new RC

Thanks - however, I'm still confused by "Task 1". Can you elaborate on what the file format you have in mind looks like, that is delimited both by newlines and by some non-newline delimiter? It seems like you could accomplish that by using a stock TextIO and applying a ParDo that splits every String on that delimiter.

For Task 2, I think we can also narrow the scope if we know more about the file format. E.g. if a delimiter is a marker line like `--- next record ---`, then we again can reuse the high-performant TextIO code for splitting bytes into lines, and then match whole lines against the delimiter.

Task 3 should be implemented altogether differently, because in that case the files should also be marked non-splittable, to avoid wastefully producing byte ranges of the file while all but the one starting at 0 will be scanned in vain and produce empty results.
Built on top of #3597, so that should be reviewed first.

Reason of this PR:
Iterables produced by GroupByKey in JStorm runner are not List. It is not equal to the expected List, even though they contain the same contents.

AssertThatHasExpectedContents is ContainsKVsInAnyOrderAndWithIterableValueInAnyOrder. It is more specific than ContainsKVs.
Sorry, forgot about this PR while on vacation. Looking.

R: @tgroh 

This came out of your review of #3334, when I turned `PipelineTranslationTest` into a more thorough test suite and things started failing. It turns out, benignly, but still...

While all pipelines are translated to/from equivalent pipelines, which you know since all execution tests pass, the verification that counts the number of coders and windowing strategies was off, because there was no attempt made to ensure that they are deserialized just once.

So this is sort of dual to `SdkComponents` but a bit simpler.

@peihe, thanks for your review.
I'll mock the RestClient to test checkVersion (mainly to verify that the exception is thrown while running the pipeline and not while configuring it) and ping you for another look.

Hmm just had another thought. What if, when applying an SDF with unbounded
output per element to a bounded collection, Flink runner does some magic
and just makes sure the watermark of that collection never goes to
infinity?.. I don't know what form this could take and it seems hacky, but
it could work. Do we even care at all about watermarks of bounded
collections in a streaming pipeline? I guess normally they advance in one
shot from -inf to +inf, and in case they are used to produce an unbounded
collection, we could just make them stay at -inf.

a manual run was triggered of the job I added (https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PerformanceTests_JDBC/171/) - it failed with 

[WARNING] Rule 2: org.apache.maven.plugins.enforcer.RequireMavenVersion failed with message:
Detected Maven Version: 3.0.5 is not in the allowed range [3.2,).

@jasonkuster speculated the problem might be that the jenkins job no longer does the setup steps for maven (ie, that they got removed with my changes), but I can't see how my changes would have affected that.


Looking further up in the file, I see this error:
[WARNING] Failed to inject repository session properties.
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.maven.execution.MavenSession.getRepositorySession()Lorg/eclipse/aether/RepositorySystemSession;
	at kr.motd.maven.os.RepositorySessionInjector.injectRepositorySession(RepositorySessionInjector.java:22)
	at kr.motd.maven.os.DetectExtension.injectSession(DetectExtension.java:151)

but I don't know if that's useful or not

I pushed another commit for the unit testing `checkVersion` using mock  that you required. But I find it is a weak test because in the end, it just tests json parsing and exception throwing as we cannot use mocks in a real pipeline because mocks are not serializable. @peihe WDYT?

I'm closing this PR because supporting Custom Windows in Spark end up being a lot more than making {{SparkGlobalCombineFn}} generic. Indeed, it requires a complete re-coding of the window merging in a way similar to what is done in {{HashingFlinkCombineRunner}}.

Issue 1
=====
last run was https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PerformanceTests_JDBC/174/console - I believe it failed because kubernetes is not installed on the machine. It failed when invoking kubernetes, and I realized we haven't done anything to install kubectl on the jenkins machines.

Issue 2
=====
I also think there's another problem we haven't hit yet, which is that we'll need the full path to maven before we can invoke it - the mvn binary on the path on this machine isn't the correct one. 

I think we have a couple options here: 
1) pass maven_binary when we run pkb.py. That means modifying the maven poms to allow users to pass in the maven_binary flag there and then passing it on as a flag to pkb.py
2) make sure the version of mvn on the path is the correct one when running this jenkins job.
3) switch this job to a regular maven job, and figure out how to compile everything AND invoke io-it-suite. That could mean switching from the "use prebuilt repo" I'm currently doing in pkb

cc @jasonkuster since I'll need your help on this

Issue 1 is correct. I'll chat with Infra to get kubernetes installed on the machines. We handle issue 2 already -- check out the 'maven_binary' arg we're passing here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/.test-infra/jenkins/common_job_properties.groovy#L245. That path should remain stable, so you can use it with no worries.
Any progress on this?

R: @sb2nov, could you make a pass over this since you initially worked on pydoc generation?

@davidcavazos 1. Do you have a hosted version of the pydoc that we can look at? 2. What does this mean for developers. If they do not use the new docs syntax, would tests fail? Or will it generate documentation with less fidelity? If it is the former, I think it deserves an email to dev@ list.
LGTM for kafka/pom.xml. Thanks.

1) Sure, you can access it through a simple HTTP server running on http://dcavazos.svl.corp.google.com:8000/target/docs/_build/
2) For developers, if they write a broken cross reference, the python documentation generation step will fail with an error, so it has to be fixed.
I think this PR is a bit premature, given that there are still open items in the merge doc. Let's please make sure everything in that doc is addressed before we start trying to merge to master.
@jbonofre said he'll take a look but I wasn't able to make much more progress beyond this.

@davidcavazos I think this deserves and email to the dev@ list, with explanation of the proposed change, what developers needs to do going forward, and how to deal with such errors and open it with discussion.

I am not sure what you mean by a broken cross reference. I am interested in following questions:
1. What happens if a function is added with no documentation?
2. What happens if a function is added with documentation but not with additional annotations. Standard comment as one of the existing things.
3. What happens if a function is added with new style comments and it has an error in it.

Ideally 1,2 should be ok, and 3 should be an error.
